hedline.hl1: Livery Cabs Testing Silent Alarm System

abstract.p: Satellite tracking systems are being tested in 40 livery cabs in New York City in an effort to curb attacks against drivers, who will be able to summon police with silent alarm (S)

block.p: In an effort to curb attacks against livery drivers, satellite tracking systems are being tested in 40 livery cabs, enabling drivers to summon the police with a silent alarm.

The system used in the 45-day pilot program enables a driver to trip a silent alarm, and dispatchers at two security companies can pinpoint the location of the cab within seconds and alert the police, officials said.
In an effort to curb attacks against livery drivers, satellite tracking systems are being tested in 40 livery cabs, enabling drivers to summon the police with a silent alarm.

The system used in the 45-day pilot program enables a driver to trip a silent alarm, and dispatchers at two security companies can pinpoint the location of the cab within seconds and alert the police, officials said.

The program could eventually put tracking devices in all 41,000 livery cabs in the city by the end of the year. It would cost about $8 million to $10 million to install and $5 million a year to maintain, officials said.
Similar satellite-based locator systems in buses have been plagued by interference from tall buildings, but livery cabs mainly work in poor neighborhoods with lower buildings.
Ten livery-cab drivers have been killed so far this year; 11 were killed in all of 1999. Late Friday, a livery driver survived an attack in which he was stabbed several times in 10 to 15 minutes.
Help might have reached the driver sooner than that, proponents of the tracking devices said, if his vehicle had been equipped with the device.
